newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada says cannot meet greenhouse gas target.
newsitem.headline: Canada says cannot meet greenhouse gas target.

text.p: Canada said on Thursday it will fail to meet its goal to stabilize greenhouse gas emissions by the year 2000, but vowed to strengthen its efforts to combat global warming.

Canada was among several countries at the 1992 Rio Earth Summit that committed to reduce greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide and methane -- the two most common gases which scientists believe contribute to global warming.
But Canadian Environment Minister Sergio Marchi confirmed on Thursday that Canada will fail to meet its goal of stabilizing emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2000.
Canadian emissions of greenhouse gases were 9.4 percent above 1990 levels last year, and are expected to stay 8 percent above 1990 levels by the year 2000.

"If we don't start to redouble the efforts. If we don't recognize that today, we won't even reach (the emission target) by 2010," Marchi said after a meeting of Canadian energy and environment ministers in Toronto.
Marchi said Canada's higher emissions were due to a growing population and stronger economy which boosted energy consumption.
The federal government unveiled a package of initiatives on Thursday, including plans to strengthen a program which asks industry to voluntarily reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
But environmental groups have said voluntary programs are not enough.

"Rather than introducing a compulsory national program to reduce greenhouse gases similar to those in other countries -- Canada has chosen instead to rely on voluntary corporate program that was flawed from the outset," said Jim Fulton, executive director of the David Suzuki Foundation, a Canadian environmental group.
Environmentalists have singled out Canada's oil and gas sector as a major offender in the battle against global warming.

The Pembina Institute of Appropriate Development said earlier this week that increased activity in Alberta's oilpatch is playing a large part in Canada's failure to see a reduction in its greenhouse gas emissions.
But Canadian petroleum producers said the industry has made significant progress in stabilizing its emissions.
The Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers (CAPP) said its figures show emissions per unit of production have been reduced by about 10 percent from 1990 to 1995.
While oil and natural gas production has increased by 33 percent over the five-year period, carbon dioxide emissions increased only 19 percent, according to CAPP's data.

Some environmentalists have pressed the government to introduce a so-called carbon tax on the energy sector. But Canadian Natural Resources Minister Anne McLellan said on Thursday that Canada has no plans to introduce such a tax.
